Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing Models of Representation and Institutional Design in the State Courts' Consideration of Inequality

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: This project aims to create a new database of judicial decisions, to measure all policies relevant to inequality in a dozen or so policy domains, in all 50 states since 1971, and to test a series of conjectures about the conditions under which the state supreme courts act to mitigate or aggravate inequality. In particular, the project will use statistical analyses to test the hypothesis that the preferences of a state?s citizenry on matters of inequality affect supreme court decisions. We further expect that this relationship depends on the methods used to select and retain judges in the state. Because the project?s timeframe encompasses the rise of interest group involvement and television advertising in judicial election, the project will also investigate how the increasing politicization of judicial elections has affected judicial responsiveness to public opinion. Overall, the analysis will be able to determine whether greater judicial accountability results in greater responsiveness to the mass public and/or to organized interests. Thus, this study will shed important new light on the causes of social, political, legal, and economic inequality in the states of the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to study the effects of state supreme courts on inequality in the American states. Work on this grant is still ongoing through a grant to Washington University in St. Louis. To date, we have developed an online coding system, written in Python code to parse state supreme court opinions, and have hired dozens of law student coders who have coded state supreme court cases in issue areas including class action, collective bargaining, mandatory arbitration, school finance, gay rights, attorneys' fees, election law, and employment at will. We have reviewed nearly 12,000 cases potentially relevant to political, legal, economic, and social inequality in the U.S., and have fully coded the more than 6,000 we confirmed as being relevant. We have begun analyzing the data and presented the first paper on the project at the 2018 APSA meeting. In that paper, we revisited Galanter’s classic argument about the “haves” and “have nots” in an age of politicized state judiciaries.  Our preliminary results emphasize the heretofore unappreciated role that state courts have played in both exacerbating and ameliorating inequality in American life. They also demonstrate important—and heretofore ignored—variation in the extent to which litigant status corresponds with inequality: in about one-quarter of our cases, the “haves” actually seek to advance equality. Future analysis will reveal how state, judge, and temporal factors affect the extent to which courts and judges vote in line with equality. The broader impacts of the project have been felt in many ways, including providing instruction on social scientific data collection and analysis methods to undergraduate, law, and Ph.D. students, through presentations to university alumni, and through publications in outlets of interest to lawyers, political scientists, and judges.
